job_title: Registered Nurse II in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Great learning environment, awesome place for new nurses (seriously), opportunity to learn about rare conditions and abnormalities, many specialties and subspecialties, IV team, phlebotomy, charge nurse opportunity surplus, unit becomes your family, took care of many Arabic princes and famous actors

JHH is for you if you have a type A personality and enjoy comparing your life to others. 

Ratios:
Cardiovascular PCU 1:3 days, 1:4 nights
Ortho trauma 1:5-6 days & nights
cons:
POLITICS! It's exhausting for someone who just wants to do their job and go home; nurses bully their young here, baseline racial targeting (if you are brown skin, you know exactly what I mean) which is strange because of the location, cafeteria selection could be better and have better hours, diet only sodas offered in full sizes, parking is awful and expensive - was more than $120/mo for staff nurses, but for doctors....$0! Managers will black ball you when attempting to advance your career on other units (just lay low). 

Nurses looking for a calm place to settle down, this is NOT it. Nurses looking for peace of mind, this is NOT it. Nurses looking for a supportive, non-punitive environment, this is NOT it. Travel nurses - this is NOT it. To my brown people: avoid if possible, but you can definitely do it, just lay low with management (no matter how down-to-earth they come off).

The culture if for those who enjoy power positions and nurses who do not want to actually be bedside. Many staff nurses hate their home lives and use JHH as a way to control something in their life. My best advice: (1) recognize the individuals that are unhappy at home and minimize contact with them, (2) don't stay at JHH too long

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Baltimore, MD
pros: decent PTO, decent scheduling, decent NRP program, strict patient ratios, staff RNs have made the unit culture overall really positive.
cons: managers do not care about employees, hospital does not pay market rate for staff RNs, my unit has 2 on calls per 6 wk period which seems abnormal for floor RN. retention is terrible, half or more of the floor is travel RNs, then many new grads, then a few long time staff who bear the brunt of the issues of retention and training. MDs are hit or miss with responding to pages and concerns. sometimes they are very attentive, other times nothing is done.

pros: Good experience with a huge variety of patient population and care environments. Resume builder. Lots of opportunity to learn new skills and work on improvement projects and take classes. Schedules can be somewhat flexible, sometimes, dependent on staffing vacancies that often go unfilled for long stretches of time. Staff with a lot of diversity.
cons: Departments and managers with standards to uphold and employee engagement. Interdepartmental communication is awful. Frequently out of important supplies & medications. 40 hour work weeks with required day/night rotation for new staff required as opposed to the typical 36 hour work weeks without extra compensation, claiming its 'worked into salaries' however pay is lower than other area hospitals. Zero attempts at employee retention, in fact I think they prefer a revolving door for nursing staff. Preference to filling critical holes with travelers rather than hiring new staff or even better, offering any incentives for employee retention. Even unit managers have been forced to manage multiple units at once permanently rather than replacing staff. So many nurses, especially in ICUs, use the opportunity to gain minimal experience to allow them to pursue advanced degrees. Pay increases are ambiguous and dismal. Benefits were cut back every year, with no more 401k matching and pensions complete eliminated. Staff is not supported as being valuable, rather, the mentality that you are working for "the big name" is prevalent. A few years ago, they fought tooth and nail to prevent the institution of a nursing union--they harassed nursing staff, intentionally created divides amongst staff and spent big bucks on big PR & legal firms to come in and propagandize. Clear that there are big cliques in many of the nursing departments and often will have difficulty working with some department leaders as they are always out of town at various conventions. Advancement can be difficult, with huge requirements for "extra" work without compensation. Obvious inequality of resources and employee appreciation efforts between different departments.

review_title: Great experience but lots of variability in quality between units
pros:
Outstanding culture, quality of care, provider relationships and resources in CCU
Exceptional leadership via "lead clinical nurse" system with leadership working shifts on the unit
Unique 6-week scheduling period that allows for more flexibility & shift switches than weekly or biweekly scheduling
cons:
Lower pay than other area hospitals
Expensive parking
Hard to use vacation time -- have to request 6 months in advance and vacation blackout during winter holidays (CCU, cannot speak to vacation scheduling on other units)
Other units I floated to were more variable in collegiality and quality of care, especially units with native staffing cleaned out by COVID disruptions.
Lots of seniority/seasoned RNs so may be stuck doing night/rotating shifts and waiting longer to charge/precept compared to other hospitals and units
Cafeteria food is really bad for some reason

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Baltimore, MD
pros: The name. The learning experience is wonderful. You will meet some amazing experienced nurses and staff that will push you to be the best you can be. So many opportunities to explore several options in where you would like to be. If you do end up on a good unit with a good manager and a great team this can be a great place to be however this is far and few between
cons: If you loved being over worked, under paid, treated like an object, given .25c raise from the company for all workers (as if that will pay your bills) definitely getting Covid and it will be kept a secret until your entire unit is out with it for you to the find out you now have it, managers that hide from you, getting pulled to other units (not by choice) and not offered critical pay as they claim you will receive, for them to decide you now have to work on Covid units you never signed up for and you don’t have a choice to say no, oh and sitting in your car crying for hrs before you come in. Well by all means work here then. It’s way to much to say about how horrible it is here. The good nurses end up leaving and your just stuck with new nurses or travel nurses with nasty attitudes that will make more money than you and cannot even do the basics. This is by far one of the worse hospitals I have worked at in my life. My Hopkins experience will forever be ruined and I was excited so much to work here but they really need to clean house and start with managers who support drama and gossip, clicks and mistreatment of human beings. I would never bring my family here for treatment. What I will say, theres some great units here to work for but the sad part is the positions stay filled and you end up getting what no one wants the places that can’t stay staff because of the problems stated

Having moved on after working here for 4 years, I sometimes wish I could go back! I now realize the value of the collaborative and autonomous environment for nursing that I enjoyed. It was a tough place to be and expectations were high on my unit, but I felt supported by my fellow nurses and I also felt that many of the residents were top-notch at listening to nursing feedback.
I also appreciate the drive to make the healthcare that was provided better, in terms of patient safety and other quality factors. Even if something fell flat, other things were tried. review_title: World Class Institution with Great Benefits
job_title: LAN Administrator B in Baltimore, MD
pros: Mostly the benefits, like health insurance, paid time off, 403b with matching and pensions after 5 years of service. There are opportunities for advancement, and tuition reimbursement. It is a world class institution that is always doing some amazing research and finding new cures for diseases. There are locations all over the city and county, so you can relocate easily within the institution. It is also a "family company" in that it usually promotes from within rather than recruiting for the outside. I feel like I could start here as a network technician, and eventually work my way up to CIO.
cons: The salary isn't always the most competitive in your field, however you need to take into account the benefits you receive, which are typically far better than the rest of the industry. It is also so large, that sometime I feel like I just push buttons all day without actually needing to use my brain. A lot of people complete their probationary period here and put their career in "cruise control", meaning they are just collecting a paycheck and waiting for retirement so they can start collecting their pensions. I think all large companies have a negative side, and Hopkins is no different.

review_title: Registered Nurse - Johns Hopkins Children's Center
pros: Good training, modern environment, state-of-the-art technology, broad experience
cons: Full time is 40 hours a week, to be completed as an "average" over 6 weeks. This means that you could work three 12 hour shifts in a row on a Thursday, Friday, Saturday which counts as 36 hours. The very next week you would work 48 hours to balance out the average, and repeat over 6 weeks. You will feel like you are doing constant overtime (without the overtime pay) with the way they stack shifts on the end of the week and then add more on the start of a new week. On top of that, most shifts are rotating days/nights to start. Myself and other nurses have been given weeks where we work every other night - which makes it impossible to have real days off in between as they are just sleep days. Morale among new nurses is low on units where hospital seniority dictates everything, especially better schedules. Johns Hopkins is also well-known for paying less than most area hospitals since their reputation will always attract a steady stream of new nurses.

review_title: JHH does not appreciate its non-physician employees
pros: Great facilities, a lot of docs here are big names in their respective fields.  You'll probably learn a lot.
cons:
Pay for nurses and NP's is at least 20% below market rate.  The benefits used to be good, but they cut them more and more every year.  For example, NP's used to get a yearly amount of $ for professional development and continuing education, but some departments took that away altogether.  NP's have to earn CE credits in order to be able to renew their certifications and licenses, but many JHH NP's now have to do so on their own dime.  This was for all intents and purposes a pay cut, and we were already getting paid well below market rate to begin with.

Meanwhile the physicians still receive annual bonuses as large as the annual pay for some lower level employees.  The administration's priorities are very clear.   

JHH and JHU are two separate institutions; JHU generally offers much better benefits.   Some NP's work for JHH, and others work for JHU.  It's complicated and not good for staff morale to have two different classes of employees working side by side.  For example, JHU employees get paid maternity leave, while JHH employees just get FMLA.

JHH also used to automatically pay a good chunk of the tuition for nurses who enroll at the JHUSON, but they no longer pay for certificate programs earned there, only full degrees.

There are a lot of big egos throughout the hospital, and this can get in the way of good, safe patient care.  And while some administrators really care about the people who work under them, many don't even pretend to.  Lastly, the sheer number of administrators at this place is mind boggling.  The scale of the bureaucracy can make change very difficult and slow to effect.

pros: The reputation of the Johns Hopkins Hospital will make your resume a converstation-starter. If you stick around and adavance within the ranks, most of the hospitals will be glad to talk to you about opportunities with their companies. The benefits at the Hospital are great: 10k for education, up to 17k for buying a house, subsidized vision, dental, and health insurance, and gyms on site. Housing is relatively cheap in Baltimore.
cons: Because there are no effective controls over doctors who bring most of the money through research, doctors forsake patient care for research. A long running hand hygiene initiative is still far from 100% compliance - doctors do not wash hands before and after seeing patients. The neglect tickles down the ranks, so patient satisfaction suffers.

pros: I think the primary pro is the JH name, and associated prestige
cons: Leadership, especially my direct supervisor, was abusive and careless.  The bureaucracy was insurmountable. Mistreatment of inferiors was rampant throughout the department, and when I made this known to Johns Hopkins HR, I was told "doesn't sound that bad." My coworkers and I disagreed with that assessment.

job_title: LAN WAN Architect in Baltimore, MD
pros: Talented, dedicated people work at Johns Hopkins.  You'll meet some of the best medical staff in the world here.  Good benefits, tuition reimbursement and lots of vacation.
cons: Salary is not up to industry standards.  Small pension and no 401 k matches.  Expensive parking options. Horrible neighborhood.

pros: While I can think of very little that I would categorize as a "pro", I suppose gaining experience working under very high stress situations in a high volume hospital is one. I also feel like having the Johns Hopkins name on your resume would help in future job searches.
cons: Where do I start? The entire orientation, they drive into your head that this is the top hospital in the country, possibly the world. I'm not so sure now that I've worked here for five years. I see, in my department, a high level of incompetence which the management refuses to acknowledge and/or do anything about. This hospital as a whole has an enormous turn around rate which means new employees constantly and starting over constantly. Instead of treating their current, seasoned employees better, they seem to prefer hiring people who cannot keep up with the volume. From my experience here, even if you voice your concerns, they don't seem to want to hear you and are afraid to get rid of dead weight. With so much negative retention, the stress of the workload falls on your good workers who tend to burn out at an incredible rate. They pay is mediocre at best and is not worth the insane workload which leads to people deciding to slack off because they don't get paid enough to do all of that work. This, unfortunately, filters down to the patient level. Care is compromised when your skilled workforce is fed up. The benefits were very good, but now they are starting this new requirement. If you want 100% coverage, you have to use a hopkins affiliated physician. If you choose not to, you are responsible for 10% of the medical bill. Problem with this is 1.) If you have a long term primary care physician that you are comfortable with and they are not a hopkins physician, you are going to pay for it. 2.) All of your labs and results are run through the main hospital and accessible to fellow employees, there have been instances of the entire department finding out about a pregnancy or other medical conditions before the employee was comfortable telling anyone. 3.) The Hopkins physicians are not everywhere, so if you happen to live out in the country, the mountains or even into a boardering state, you may not have a hopkins physician anywhere nearby to go to. So now, the pay is getting cut all around the hospital (except for the executives and upper management), they have taken control over your choices in benefits and the area the main campus is in is dangerous and unsafe. Since I've been there (going on 5 years) there have been TWO gunman in the hospital and there are no major steps being taken to make the place any safer.

review_title: Stay away from Johns Hopkins Healthcare in Glen Burnie
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Glen Burnie, MD
pros: Only pro is that other employers recognize Johns Hopkins as an elite organization when you apply for your next job. New hire orientation is great, but gives you a false sense of what is to come.
cons: There is an overwelming abundance of poor directors and managers at this place, especially within the Finance dept. The most I have ever seen in an organization. Pay is a joke. Expect your salary to stay pretty close to whatever you were hired in at. Top salary percent increase is between 3-4%-and that is with a perfect performance rating. Lack of accountability in higher level management. Little to no recognition is given to hardest workers. No mentors or training programs for new hires, so when you start it's every man for himself. Lack of communication, organized procedures and processes causes employees to do a lot of double work that other employees and departments are already doing, so inefficient is putting it lightly. Overall employees are very unhappy, overworked and stressed here. Dont be fooled by the Hopkins name. They do not seem to care about ensuring that all managers (including execs) have appropriate interpersonal skills to manage others. No management training is enforced. Decisions are mostly made based on how things look,rather than what is right or makes sense. How things effect lower on totem poll workers seem unimportant as long as it makes a mgr look good. Very very political and old fashioned heirarchical structure. Very high turnover. A million unnecessary meetings saying the same things over and over,with no real agenda. Need I say more?
